;澳大利亚国防部因 2.5 米（ 8 英尺长）的咸水鳄鱼咬伤了两名在受感染水域游泳的士兵。

;

;这两名军人（一名二等兵和一名下士）从爬行动物的嘴里逃脱后被送往医院，该爬行动物于 8 月份发动袭击2021 年，他们去澳大利亚东北部的约克角半岛游泳。

;

;两人获准乘坐 Zodiac 充气船前往偏远地区钓鱼，该地区位于澳大利亚以北约 750 公里（450 英里）处。昆士兰州凯恩斯市。

;

;澳大利亚工作健康和安全监管机构 Comcare 周五表示，船停泊后，他们跳入水中，“几乎立即”遭到鳄鱼的袭击。

;

;政府机构表示：“鳄鱼将一名士兵拖到水下并殴打他，而他的同事则与鳄鱼搏斗，让这些人逃到了黄道十二宫。”

;

;澳大利亚的一名男子赶走了一名士兵。鳄鱼变鱼。然后其中两个把他吃了

;

;两名士兵都受了重伤，有咬伤和爪伤，他们在凯恩斯医院接受治疗。

;

;检察官对国防部提出了一项指控Comcare 称，该部门违反了联邦工作健康和安全法。

;

;该部门被指控未能执行多项政策：在没有运营或安全原因的情况下，禁止工人进入鳄鱼栖息的水域；进行风险评估；并提供有关鳄鱼袭击风险的详细安全简报。

;

;当士兵们决定参加这次不幸的游泳时，他们正从达尔文基地乘坐登陆艇前往汤斯维尔进行维护。< /p>;

;如果罪名成立，最高处罚为 150 万澳元（98 万美元）。

;

;国防部感谢社区成员和急救人员在袭击后为这两人提供帮助。< /p>;

;“我们人民的安全在所有活动中都是最重要的，对于我们捍卫澳大利亚及其国家利益的使命至关重要，”它在一份声明中表示。

;

;国防部确认了一项已对其提出指控，但拒绝进一步置评，理由是正在进行的法律诉讼。

;美国总统乔·拜登要求议员批准数十亿美元，与众议院共和党人发生冲突更多资金用于乌克兰国防，进一步限制国会避免 10 月 1 日政府关门的能力。

;

;白宫预计将为乌克兰战争费用提供 130 亿美元资金，其中包括 400 亿美元补充资金随着冲突进入更加激烈的阶段，支出请求对于维持对俄罗斯的战争努力至关重要。但随着保守派强烈反对美国卷入战争，共和党对援助的反对情绪日益强烈。

;

;科罗拉多州共和党众议员劳伦·博伯特 (Lauren Boebert) 在社交媒体平台 X 上表示：“答案必须是否定的！”以前称为推特。 “我们已经做得足够多了，这些钱甚至都没有经过审计。”

;

;该计划指定为乌克兰和相关国际紧急情况提供 240 亿美元，其中包括 95 亿美元用于向基辅和乌克兰运送军事装备。根据白宫情况说明书，补充国防部库存。

;

;持续的军事、情报和其他支持将另外花费 36 亿美元，同时预留 110 亿美元用于经济、人道主义和发展援助。额外的85亿美元经济和人道主义请求包括向被俄罗斯瓦格纳集团雇佣军围困的非洲国家提供2亿美元的援助。

;

;国防援助预计将持续到明年第一季度末，一位向记者介绍该计划的高级政府官员表示。

;

;美国称赞中国参加沙特领导的乌克兰和平谈判“富有成效”

;

;未能批准乌克兰的资金将标志着战争爆发近 18 个月后，这是美国的分水岭。国会已在三个不同场合通过了乌克兰援助计划，最近一次是在去年 12 月，没有引起太多争议。

;

;这也将动摇拜登帮助组建的跨大西洋联盟，该联盟旨在为乌克兰军队提供武器和训练，事实证明，这些联盟对于乌克兰军队来说至关重要。基辅为阻止俄罗斯军队占领该国而做出的努力。

;

;美国参议院两党对乌克兰援助的支持一直保持稳定，但这笔资金在众议院却引起了争议，众议院议长凯文·麦卡锡 (Kevin McCarthy) 承诺不会向乌克兰提供援助。如果援助计划绕过五月债务上限协议中规定的国防支出上限，则该援助计划将降至最低。

;

;保守派议员对该协议的条款仍然感到愤怒，并表示他们不会支持为基辅提供更多资金没有任何附加条件。其他人则从根本上反对协助乌克兰的战争努力。上个月，70 名众议院共和党议员（几乎占共和党会议的三分之一）投票决定完全切断援助。

;

;向乌克兰提供资金的请求附加在 120 亿美元的额外救灾资金中，这可以帮助整个包裹顺利通过。联邦机构还要求为在本山火季节与大火作斗争并面临迫在眉睫的资金短缺的联邦机构消防员提供 6000 万美元的工资。

;

;FEMA 预计其目前的救灾基金余额为 6.4 美元由于灾难性灾难支出，到本财政年度结束时，100 亿美元将用完，到 9 月 30 日将出现 43 亿美元的赤字。

;

;这 120 亿美元计划持续到本财政年度结束据一位高级政府官员称，这一计划是根据对灾难恢复的当前和长期需求的估计而计算的。

;

;拜登周三表示，在致命的野火席卷夏威夷后，他将向夏威夷紧急提供联邦支持毛伊岛。

;

;该请求还包括 40 亿美元用于边境安全和缓解移民问题。它不包括在中国威胁加剧的情况下加快向台北转移武器的资金，尽管有传言称可能会这样做。

;

;如果乌克兰进攻成功，俄罗斯将拥有核武器：前总统梅德韦杰夫

;<参议院民主党领袖查克·舒默表示，该追加资金请求得到了众议院两党的大力支持，他表示，这一请求“应该向弗拉基米尔·普京、中国政府和其他人发出明确的信号，表明美国在捍卫世界民主方面的决心”。

;

;众议院将于下个月结束八月休会，届时它将必须处理补充请求以及下一个财政年度的总体政府资助措施。

;

;众议院和参议院以及民主党和共和党之间在可自由支配支出水平上的深刻分歧增加了 9 月 30 日资金到期时政府关门的风险。

;

;国会 12 月通过了 450 亿美元的额外资金乌克兰的战争努力本应持续到下个月结束的财政年度。立法者此前于 2022 年 5 月批准了 400 亿美元，并于 2022 年 3 月批准了 136 亿美元，迄今为止总计 986 亿美元。

;一家中国辅导公司已同意就美国政府机构提起的新颖诉讼达成和解该公司使用人工智能驱动的招聘软件非法淘汰年龄较大的求职者。

;

;2022 年针对 iTutorGroup 的诉讼是美国平等就业机会委员会 (EEOC) 提起的第一起涉及公司使用人工智能创造就业机会的诉讼

;

;该委员会负责执行工作场所偏见法，于 2021 年发起了一项举措，以确保美国雇主使用的人工智能软件符合反歧视法。平等就业机会委员会警告称，它将重点打击滥用人工智能的公司。

;

;根据 2019 年提交的一份联合文件，ITutorGroup 同意向 200 多名据称因年龄而被淘汰的求职者支付 365,000 美元。周三，纽约联邦法院。该和解协议必须得到联邦法官的批准。

;

;这家为中国学生提供英语辅导的公司否认在和解协议中存在不当行为。

;

;平等就业机会委员会指控 iTutorGroup 2020 年，该公司编写了在线招聘软件，筛选出 55 岁或以上的女性和 60 岁或以上的男性。

;

;中国平安保险集团旗下的 ITutorGroup 没有立即回复置评请求。平等就业机会委员会发言人表示，在和解获得批准之前，该机构不会发表评论。

;

;根据最近的调查，至少 85% 的美国大型雇主在就业的某些​​方面使用人工智能。

;

Not reallyhttps://www.scmp.com/week-asia/opinion/article/3230611/will-china-be-offended-asean-openly-backing-heightened-us-security-presence-region-not-really?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.08.11 10:30;

;东南亚国家越来越多地选择遵守“让我们不要冒犯中国”的路线公开表达他们私下的感受。这是我最近与分析师就两个不同主题进行对话时得到的印象。

;

;关于北约扩大在亚太地区的影响力，一位观察家表示，东南亚政界人士公开表达了对欧洲安全联盟的担忧他说，这样做是为了“确保中国不被冒犯”，但私下里，这些国家欢迎北约、华盛顿和其他多边组织

;

;在讨论日本最新的防务白皮书时，一位东南亚分析人士表示，该地区国家对东京的表现感到担忧，该白皮书将北京称为该国“最大的战略挑战”。 reacting militarily to China's historic rise.

;

;But behind closed doors, the analyst said that regional elites understand and even support Japan's more muscular policies towards China, given their experience with Beijing's maritime expansion.

;

;This is especially so in countries like Vietnam and the Philippines which for years have had skirmishes with Chinese vessels in the disputed South China Sea.

;

;Philippines needs new trade deals to pivot away from China, lawmakers urge;

;The aversion to state their private thoughts is unsurprising as Asean generally hedges between the United States, whom the 10-member bloc sees as a long-time security provider, and China, its largest and even somewhat indispensable economic development partner .

;

;For instance, while welcoming American bases on its soil, Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jnr said the US cannot use them for “offensive action” against Beijing in the event of a future war over Taiwan.

;

;This is done arguably not to jeopardise Manila's US$87.725 billion bilateral trade with China last year.

;

;Thailand, a US treaty ally, has allowed Washington to use its U-Tapao airbase and in April hosted a port visit by the USS Nimitz carrier strike group.

;

;But under Bangkok's “bamboo diplomacy” – which called for a careful balancing between greater powers – the kingdom also held a joint air combat exercise (Falcon Strike 2023) with China last month.

;

;It also hosted the World Chinese Entrepreneurs Convention in June to draw more investments from the Asian giant, while its ambassador to China last Friday hailed the Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) for fostering connectivity .

;

;Arthayudh Srisamoot's comments were surely welcomed in Beijing at a time when Italy has indicated its desire to leave the global initiative aimed at building infrastructure and connectivity, describing its plan to join the scheme as an “atrocious” decision .

;

;As for Vietnam, it has strengthened military and political relations with the US and Australia in recent months, but is dragging its feet on upgrading its ties with Washington from a “comprehensive” to a “strategic” one .

;

;The reason: it did not want to antagonise China as the elevated alliance includes increased defence cooperation and American weapons supplies. Nor does Hanoi want to be openly seen as being part of the US strategy designed to counter Beijing.

;

;But the question is, will China necessarily be “offended”?

;

;As a shrewd major force in Asia, Beijing clearly understands the concerns of regional countries who undertake a balancing act between the superpowers.

;

;'Clearly a concern': Japan's hardening China stance sparks regional unease

;

;China cannot not see through the hedging strategies of these Southeast Asian countries, and is aware that for the sake of continued goodwill and economic opportunities, these states have chosen not to say in open how they feel in private.

;

;As Chinese scholars Zhu Lubin and Huang Haibin wrote in the Journal of Qiqihar University in 2021, while Hanoi looks to Beijing for economic benefits, it also “seeks to prevent a rising China from posing security threats and hopes to obtain further military support from the US.”

;

;Of course, this is not to say that Southeast Asian countries should openly declare that they welcome the greater involvement of other powers in the region to counter Chinese influence.

;

;Asian reticence and decorum would not have allowed that, not to mention the anxiety about rocking the economic boat, especially for the smaller nations that are more dependent on China such as Laos and Cambodia.

;

;But even if they had openly stated what they feel in private, I am doubtful that Beijing would have been offended.

;

;While there might be an immediate short-term diplomatic price to pay for voicing views that Beijing finds unpalatable, I am certain that for its own strategic and economic interests, China would continue to engage its neighbourhood economically, diplomatically and militarily in the longer term.

;The death toll from a terrifying wildfire that razed a historic Hawaiian town hit 53 on Thursday, making it one of the deadliest disasters to strike the islands since they became a US state.

;

;Brushfires on the west coast of Hawaii's Maui island – fuelled by high winds from a nearby hurricane – broke out Tuesday and rapidly engulfed the seaside town of Lahaina.

;

;The flames moved so quickly that many were caught off guard, trapped in the streets or jumping into the ocean in a desperate bid to escape.

;

;“In 1960 we had 61 fatalities when a large wave came through Big Island,” Governor Josh Green said, referring to a tragedy that struck a year after Hawaii became the 50th US state.

;

;“This time, it's very likely that our death totals will significantly exceed that.”

;

;Officials in Maui County said Thursday the confirmed number of dead now stood at 53, and firefighters were still battling the blaze.

;

;'Hell on Earth': thousands more evacuated as Greece 'at war' with fires

;

;In terms of casualties, it is the second worst wildfire disaster in the US over the past 100 years after a 2018 wildfire in California that killed 85 people, US media reported.

;

;Lahaina on Thursday lay in charred, smoking ruins, with Green saying 80 per cent of the town was gone.

;

;“There is no doubt everyone would describe this as though a bomb hit Lahaina,” he said. “看起来像是彻底的毁灭； buildings that we've all enjoyed and celebrated together for decades, for generations, are completely destroyed.”

;

;US President Joe Biden on Thursday declared the fires a “major disaster” and unblocked federal aid for relief efforts, as residents said they needed more help in a recovery that could take years.

;

;US Coast Guard commander Aja Kirksey told CNN around 100 people were believed to have jumped into the water in a desperate effort to flee the fast-moving flames as they tore through Lahaina.

;

;Kirksey said helicopter pilots struggled to see because of the dense smoke pouring from the huge fire, but that a Coast Guard vessel had been able to rescue more than 50 people from the water.

;

;“It was a really rapidly developing scene and pretty harrowing for the victims that had to jump into the water,” she added.

;

;Canada wildfires spark 'ecoterrorist' conspiracy theory

;

;For resident Kekoa Lansford, the horror was far from over.

;

;“We still get dead bodies in the water floating and on the sea wall,” Lansford told CBS.

;

;“We have been pulling people out … We're trying to save people's lives, and I feel like we are not getting the help we need.”

;

;Aerial photographs of Lahaina, which served as the Hawaiian kingdom's capital in the early 19th century, showed entire blocks reduced to cinders.

;

;Green said around 1,700 buildings were now believed to have been affected by the blaze.

;

;“With lives lost and properties decimated, we are grieving with each other during this inconsolable time,” Maui Mayor Richard Bissen said.

;

;Wildfires sparked 'Great Dying' of 250 million years ago, Chinese study confirms

;

;“In the days ahead, we will be stronger as a … community,” he added, “as we rebuild with resilience and aloha.”

;

;Thousands of people have already been evacuated from Maui, with 1,400 people waiting at the main airport in Kahului overnight, hoping to get out.

;

;Maui County has asked visitors to leave “as soon as possible,” and has organised buses to move evacuees from shelters to the airport.

;

;The island hosts around a third of all the visitors who holiday in the state, and their dollars are vital for the local economy.

;

;Fires have also broken out on Hawaii's Big Island, but officials said they were under control on Thursday.

;

;The state's tourism chief Jimmy Tokioka acknowledged the tragedy but reiterated that the “rest of Hawaii is open”.

;

;With a hurricane passing to the south of Hawaii, high winds fuelled flames that consumed dry vegetation.

;

;Thomas Smith, a professor with the London School of Economics, said that while wildfires are not uncommon in Hawaii, the blazes this year “are burning a greater area than usual, and the fire behaviour is extreme, with fast spread rates and large flames”.

;

;The Hawaii fires follow other extreme weather events this summer in North America, with record-breaking wildfires still burning across Canada and a major heatwave baking the US southwest.

;

;Europe and parts of Asia have also endured soaring temperatures, with major fires and floods wreaking havoc.

;

;As global temperatures rise over time, heatwaves are projected to become more frequent, with increased dryness due to changing rainfall patterns creating ideal conditions for bush or forest fires.
